channel.title: XOR Problem
channel.description:
I'm just beginning to examine the client, and already I've stumbled upon a problem. :(
The recent revisions require six arguments when ran through [font=courier][size=10pt]main[/size][/font]. Here is the bytecode that checks the argument count: [code] aload_0 arraylength iconst_m1 ixor bipush 249 if_icmpeq label1 iconst_0 ldc_w <Argument count> invokestatic <h/error(ZLjava/lang/String;)V> label1: etc. [/code]
However, [font=courier][size=10pt]6 ^ -1[/size][/font] evaluates to -7 and not 249... so wtf???

item.title: XOR Problem
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“c|p, post:10, topic:336710”]all java types are signed.

you are just confused because the viewer/editor you are using displays bipush values as unsigned, it is still a signed byte (-> two’s complement).[/quote]yeh, that’s what I was trying to get at; signed or unsigned is a way you interpret the same exact binary sequence – 101 could be 5 or it could be -3
lesson learned: JBE sucks dick and I will forever resort to javap

Read full topic

item.title: XOR Problem
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

all java types are signed.

you are just confused because the viewer/editor you are using displays bipush values as unsigned, it is still a signed byte (-> two’s complement).

Read full topic

item.title: XOR Problem
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:6, topic:336710”]incorrect[/quote]my question about ZKM or my explanation?

[quote=“BAsh, post:7, topic:336710”]bipush pushes a BYTE onto the stack.[/quote]yes, an 8-bit integer, so it can only exceed 128 if it is unsigned (i.e., it didn’t use the leftmost bit specially)…

[quote=“BAsh, post:7, topic:336710”]if_icmp* wants a INTEGER. so a B2I instruction is used.[/quote]no? the bipush instruction automatically converts to an int: “The immediate byte is sign-extended to an int value. That value is pushed onto the operand stack” [spec].

if_icmpeq treats both popped ints as having a special leftmost bit (“All comparisons are signed” [spec]), so the pushed byte evaluates to -7…

Read full topic

item.title: XOR Problem
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

fyi bytes, shorts, chars and booleans are treated as ints on the stack

ps jbe sucks dicks

Read full topic

item.title: XOR Problem
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

bipush pushes a BYTE onto the stack. if_icmp* wants a INTEGER. so a B2I instruction is used. 255 (byte) = -1 (int)

Read full topic

item.title: XOR Problem
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“c|p, post:2, topic:336710”]http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two’s_complement[/quote]thanks, c|p

so the answer is in the bipush instruction: Java expects a two’s complementary / signed byte as an operand, but the bytecode pushes an unsigned byte 249:
1111 1001
the if_icmpeq comes around the corner and interprets this binary as two’s complementary / signed (well, basically all instruction do, no?), which evalutes to -7 (gasp! just like 6 ^ -1!!) so execution continues and I can now proceed to further examine the client

edit: c|p, damnit it was supposed to be “how are you gentlemen!!!” in the karma reason

edit2: this is ZKM-generated code, correct?

Read full topic

item.title: XOR Problem
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

I’m just beginning to examine the client, and already I’ve stumbled upon a problem.

The recent revisions require six arguments when ran through [font=courier][size=10pt]main[/size][/font]. Here is the bytecode that checks the argument count:

aload_0
arraylength
iconst_m1
ixor
bipush 249
if_icmpeq label1
iconst_0
ldc_w <Argument count>
invokestatic <h/error(ZLjava/lang/String;)V>
  label1:
etc.

However, [font=courier][size=10pt]6 ^ -1[/size][/font] evaluates to -7 and not 249… so wtf???

Read full topic
